instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> drawing .100A and is missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is missing, in fact , it seems I am missing all 4 PGOOD signals. No sign of liquid damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You can't look at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> when missing S3 voltages.
It requires sum of several S5, S3 and even S0 voltages.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS stable?
Did you try SMC bypass mode?
Are you using original Magsafe 2 charger?

Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and all RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
3V3S5/SUS is a Stable 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PS_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>: 3.2V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
PCH_INTERVRMEN: 3.2V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>: 3.03V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Using original MS2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post now <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So PP3V42 was shorted to GND. found that the SMC was causing it so I replaced it. When I fired it up it was drawing 500mA and fan spin. I turned it off and put the board back in to the chassis, turned it on and now it is drawing 23mA but I have an orange light. I swear this board is possessed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Had to replace <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. Board working now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Nevermind, this is the wrong board, this one still not working

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> :3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.4V

when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops then recovers

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This one is solved. Was <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> IC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
And which is that chip???
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> connects with a lot of ICs.
And it comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, through <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>.
The other chips and resistors can only pull it down to ground...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Oh ok. The one I replaced was <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I found that by measuring all of the rails required to get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and found none were missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So all of S0 were present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Probably not the best way, but I have a working LB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: And I looked at the data sheet for that IC, pin 4 is the "ouput" pin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Wait, wrong one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sorry, but anyway, you get the point

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok I get it, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> goes through <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>, becomes <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> to <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>, then becomes <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You can remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and throw it, not really needed.
If board works then, you can leave it as is; or find what is wrong on <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> inputs.
